Uses of Class
gui.Explanation

  • Packages that use Explanation 
    Package Description
    gui
    This package provides classes realizing the user interface and the handling of a user session in the program.
    semantics.ranking
    This package provides classes implementing ranking functions for propositional and first-order formulas and conditionals as well as system Z approaches to compute such ranking functions for a knowledge base.

    • Uses of Explanation in gui

      Methods in gui with parameters of type Explanation 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean Session.askQuery(String query, Explanation exp)
      Evaluates a query against the computed ranking function.
      private void GUI.switchOutput(boolean isTree, Explanation exp)
      Switches between the text output area and the tree control used to show detailed query evaluations.
      Constructors in gui with parameters of type Explanation 
      Constructor and Description
      Explanation(boolean parent, Explanation node, String text)
      Creates a new explanation tree node below or above the given node.
      Explanation(Explanation parent)
      Creates a new explanation tree node below the given parent node.
      Explanation(Explanation parent, String text)
      Creates a new explanation tree node below the given parent node.

    • Uses of Explanation in semantics.ranking

      Methods in semantics.ranking with parameters of type Explanation 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean ExplainedRankingFunction.accepts(Collection<Conditional<I>> conditionals, Explanation exp)
      Determines whether a set of conditionals is accepted by the ranking function, which is the case if all conditionals are accepted by the ranking function.
      boolean ExplainedRankingFunction.accepts(Conditional<I> c, Explanation exp)
      Determines whether the given conditional is accepted by the ranking function, which is the case if the conditionals verification has a lower rank than its falsification.
      boolean ExplainedRelationalRankingFunction.accepts(Conditional<RelationalAtom> c, Explanation exp)
      Checks whether an open first-order conditional is accepted by the ranking function, which is the case if the conditional has at least one representative and a) the verification of the conditional has a lower rank than its falsification or b) both have the same rank, but all instantiations of the falsification formula with the conditionals representatives have lower ranks than all instantiations of the verification formula with representatives of the negated conditional.
      boolean ExplainedRankingFunction.accepts(Formula<I> f, Explanation exp)
      Determines whether a formula is accepted, which is the case if it is satisfied in all worlds ranked most plausible, i.e.
      boolean ExplainedRelationalRankingFunction.accepts(Formula<RelationalAtom> f, Explanation exp)
      Checks whether an open first-order formula F is accepted by the ranking function, which is the case if the open conditional (F|true) is accepted.
      int ExplainedRankingFunction.getFalsificationRank(Conditional<I> c, Explanation exp)
      Returns the rank of the conditional's falsification formula, i.e.
      int ExplainedRankingFunction.getRank(Conditional<I> c, Explanation exp)
      Returns the rank for a conditional, which is the difference between the rank of its verification and the rank of its antecedence.
      int ExplainedRelationalRankingFunction.getRank(Conditional<RelationalAtom> c, Explanation exp)
      Returns the rank for an open first-order conditional, which is the minimal rank of all of its instantiations, or RankingFunction.INFINITY, if there is no such instantiation.
      int ExplainedRankingFunction.getRank(Formula<I> f, Explanation exp)
      Returns the rank for a formula, which is the minimal rank of all worlds in which the formula is satisfied, or RankingFunction.INFINITY, if there is no such world.
      int ExplainedRelationalRankingFunction.getRank(Formula<RelationalAtom> f, Explanation exp)
      Returns the rank for an open first-order formula, which is the minimal rank of all of its possible instantiations, or RankingFunction.INFINITY, if there is no such instantiation.
      Collection<Constant> ExplainedRelationalRankingFunction.getRepresentatives(RelationalConditional c, Explanation exp)
      Returns the set of representatives for an open conditional.
      int ExplainedRankingFunction.getVerificationRank(Conditional<I> c, Explanation exp)
      Returns the rank of the conditional's verification formula, i.e.
      Collection<Constant> ExplainedRelationalRankingFunction.getWeakRepresentatives(RelationalConditional c, Explanation exp)
      Returns all weak representatives for an open conditional.
